subject: RE: [junit] Tradeoff btw. right design and performance
msgSnippet: So said  Chappell, Simon P  on  2002-10-17 ... You *never* *have* to do anything; however, the more you refactor, the better your design. If your design is
messageBody:
So said Chappell, Simon P on 2002-10-17

>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: Rytrom [mailto:roman@...]
>>Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2002 11:16 AM
>>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>>Subject: [junit] Tradeoff btw. right design and performance
>
><snip>
>
>>Why I'm asking this question in JUint group is 'cause I started
>>practicing JUint recently and one of my badly-designed classes
>>happened to be untestable (cause of such thought copling).
>>As buffs of XP approach what do you preffer? Does it mean that every
>>time a unit test can't be written for a function the function must be

>>refactored?

You *never* *have* to do anything; however, the more you refactor, the
better your design. If your design is untestable and you need to test
it, change your design or change your testing approach. Sometimes it's
better to test a bigger piece of the puzzle, if the alternative is not
to test at all.

J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
